name: Evidence Extraction Quality (v1)
description: Lightweight eval for extracting structured experimental details (configs, results, constraints) from research text with minimal hallucination.
judge_preamble: You are an evaluator for a research assistant that extracts structured experiment details from text. Prefer faithful extraction over speculation. Penalize hallucinated values.

criteria: Fidelity: extracted facts match the provided text (no hallucinated values).
Coverage: captures required fields and key constraints mentioned in the text.
Traceability: cites short evidence quotes/snippets for each major field (or marks unknown).
Structure: output is valid JSON and uses the requested schema.

cases.prompt:
Extract the experiment into JSON with fields: {"task", "hardware", "software", "workload", "metrics", "results", "controls", "notes", "evidence"} where "evidence" is a map from field name to a short quote.

TEXT:
We evaluated the change on a dual-socket server with Intel Xeon Gold 6230 (Cascade Lake), 192GB RAM. The kernel was Linux 6.6. We compiled with GCC 13.2 using -O3.
Workload: a Monte Carlo simulation (10^8 iterations). We pinned to a single NUMA node and disabled turbo.
Metric: runtime (seconds), averaged over 10 runs; we report mean and stddev.
Result: baseline 12.4s ±0.2; patched 11.1s ±0.1 (~10.5% speedup).
Control: Verified identical input seeds and CPU affinity; collected perf stat for cycles/instructions.

Extract into JSON with fields: {"claim", "setup", "table", "confounders", "recommended_followups", "evidence"}. "table" must include columns and rows.

TEXT:
Claim: The new scheduling heuristic reduces tail latency.
Setup: 3-node cluster, 25GbE, client load 5k req/s. We used Ubuntu 22.04 and OpenJDK 21. GC was G1.
Table 1 (p99 latency, ms):
- Baseline: 42.1
- New heuristic: 34.8
We did not isolate NIC offload settings and did not report CPU frequencies.
Follow-ups: rerun with fixed CPU governor; report NIC offload and IRQ pinning; include median and p50.
